title: Simple Ways to Find the Greatest Common Factor (GCF) of Numbers

steps.title: Find factors of the number.
steps.content: Find factors of the number. You don't have to know prime factorization to find the greatest common factor. Start by finding all the factors of the set you are comparing. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Compare the sets of factors until you find the biggest number that's in both sets.
steps.content: Compare the sets of factors until you find the biggest number that's in both sets.

steps.title: Factor
steps.content: Factor each number completely into its prime numbers. [3] X Research source A prime number is number greater than 1 that has no factors but itself. Examples of prime numbers include 5, 17, 97, and 331, to name just a few.

steps.title: Identify any common prime factors.
steps.content: Identify any common prime factors. [4] X Research source Pick out any prime numbers between the set that are the same. There can be several common factors, one common factor, or none.

steps.title: Calculate:
steps.content: Calculate: If there are no common factors then the greatest common factor is 1. If there's only one prime common factor, then that's your common factor. If there are multiple prime common factors, then multiply all the prime common factors together to get your greatest common factor [5] X Research source .

steps.title: To demonstrate this method, study this example.
steps.content: To demonstrate this method, study this example.
